bill_title: define marital and nonmarital property for the purposes of the division of property between parties at divorce.

bill_versions.bill_text: FOR AN ACT ENTITLED, An Act to define marital and nonmarital property for the purposes of the division of property between parties at divorce. BE IT ENACTED BY THE LEGISLATURE OF THE STATE OF SOUTH DAKOTA: Section 1. That § 25-4-44 be amended to read as follows: 25-4-44. When a divorce is granted, the courts court may make an equitable division of the marital property belonging to either or both, whether the title to such property is in the name of the husband or the wife. In making such division of the property, the court shall have regard for equity and the circumstances of the parties. Section 2. That chapter 25-4 be amended by adding thereto a NEW SECTION to read as follows: For the purposes of § 25-4-44, nonmarital property is all property: (1) Acquired prior to the marriage; (2) Acquired by inheritance or gift from any third party or source; (3) Excluded by valid agreement; (4) That is the direct result of the increase in value of assets that are nonmarital property. All other assets of the parties are marital property. Section 3. That chapter 25-4 be amended by adding thereto a NEW SECTION to read as follows: Nonmarital property does not become marital property solely because of commingling. However, the increase in value of assets that are nonmarital property may be marital property if: (1) Appreciation was the result of investment of marital property in the nonmarital property; or (2) Appreciation was the result of marital labor in managing or improving the nonmarital property.

FOR AN ACT ENTITLED, An Act to define marital and nonmarital property for the purposes of the division of property between parties at divorce. BE IT ENACTED BY THE LEGISLATURE OF THE STATE OF SOUTH DAKOTA: Section 1. That § 25-4-44 be amended to read as follows: 25-4-44. When a divorce is granted, the courts court may make an equitable division of the marital property belonging to either or both, whether the title to such property is in the name of the husband or the wife. In making such division of the property, the court shall have regard for equity and the circumstances of the parties. The court may consider the nonmarital property when determining an equitable division of property, the need of a spouse for support, and the ability to provide support. Section 2. That chapter 25-4 be amended by adding thereto a NEW SECTION to read as follows: For the purposes of § 25-4-44, there is a rebuttable presumption that nonmarital property is all property: (1) Acquired prior to the marriage; (2) Acquired by inheritance or gift from any third party or source; (3) Excluded by valid agreement; (4) That is the direct result of the increase in value of assets that are nonmarital property. All other assets of the parties are marital property. Section 3. That chapter 25-4 be amended by adding thereto a NEW SECTION to read as follows: Nonmarital property does not become marital property solely because of commingling. However, the increase in value of assets that are nonmarital property may be marital property if: (1) Appreciation was the result of investment of marital property in the nonmarital property; or (2) Appreciation was the result of marital labor in managing or improving the nonmarital property.
